text.headline: Global Climate Apartheid: Mapping Three Dimensions of Injustice
text.text: This storymap explores three dimensions of climate injustice: causes, consequences, and responses.

text.headline: Injustice #1: Uneven responsibility for causing the climate crisis
text.text: Not everyone has contributed equally to unleashing climate chaos.

text.headline: International carbon inequality over time
text.text:
Rich countries bear more responsibility than poor countries for producing the climate crisis.

Mapping cumulative greenhouse gas emissions from fossil fuels and industrial processes (Manchester is where the coal-powered industrial revolution began) makes clear the Global North’s outsized contribution to rising temperatures.

text.headline: International carbon inequality persists today
text.text:
Mapping per capita consumption-based carbon dioxide emissions from 2021 (i.e., emissions that have been adjusted for trade) confirms that the Global North’s outsized contribution to climate change is not just historical but ongoing.

Today, Wall Street and other financial power centers exert considerable influence over the shape of our global economy and ecology.

text.headline: Carbon inequality within countries is significant
text.text:
While it’s crucial to highlight international inequality in greenhouse gas pollution, it’s equally crucial to not lose sight of intra-national carbon inequality.

The residents of Ferguson, Missouri, and Beverly Hills, California, for instance, do not contribute equally to the problem. 

In every region of the world, the richest 10% generate far more planet-heating emissions on a per capita basis than the poorest 50%. Supplementing national-level statistics, which obscure variation within countries, with income- and wealth-based data can help demonstrate the necessity of attacking socioeconomic and carbon inequality simultaneously and at all scales.

While wealthy elites' overconsumption is a major problem, their private control over investment decisions is arguably even more important. That is what has imposed resource-profligate lifestyles on millions of workers (e.g., automobility and detached single-family homes in suburbs proved more profitable than mass transit and dense social housing) and stymied a green transition (i.e., a more equitable and democratic society would move faster to produce clean energy and phase out fossil fuels).

text.headline: ... and getting worse
text.text:
The share of global carbon inequality attributable to within-country inequality has increased over the past three decades.

The development of deeply unequal cities in the Global South, such as Mumbai, only underscores the pressing need to pursue decarbonization and downward redistribution concurrently and across scales.

text.headline: Injustice #2: Those who have done the least to cause the crisis face its worst consequences
text.text: Despite bearing far less responsibility for the climate crisis, impoverished countries—especially their poorest residents—face the brunt of its current and future impacts.

text.headline: Inhospitable temperatures are projected to affect some of the world's poorest regions
text.text:
In “Future of the human climate niche,” Xu et al. (2021) warn that under a high-emissions and low-migration scenario, one-third of the global population in 2070 is likely to endure a mean annual temperature greater than 29°C (84.2°F). As of 2020, such dangerous conditions were “found in only 0.8% of the Earth’s land surface.”

Using data provided in the paper, I mapped the projected growth of this deadly milieu, which is expected to expand from essentially a few areas in the Sahara to encompass a wide swath of densely populated land between the Tropic of Cancer and the Tropic of Capricorn.

This will put hundreds of millions of people, many of them poor and having done little to drive the climate crisis, directly in harm’s way.

Haiti, for example, is one of many Caribbean nations where intensifying heat will endanger public health, and many countries in Central America, Africa, and Southeast Asia are also at heightened risk.

text.headline: Injustice #3: The primary response to the crisis so far is more militarization and border fortification
text.text:
There’s still time to avert the climate emergency’s most catastrophic effects. And yet, even as the window for lifesaving action rapidly closes, rich nations continue to invest more in militarization and border fortification than in risk mitigation, green adaptation, and compensation for locked-in damages.

This does not bode well for humanity, as it pushes us closer to eco-fascism and further from a just transition.

text.headline: Global military spending outpaces climate finance for developing countries
text.text:
From 2013 to 2022, governments worldwide spent roughly 29 times more on militarism than on climate finance for low-income nations.

The leading offender has been the United States, which has reneged on its climate commitments while spending more on its military than the next nine countries combined.

text.headline: Rich countries are spending significantly more to militarize their borders than to support climate action in poor countires
text.text:
From 2013 to 2018, the United States, Canada, and Australia spent nearly five times more on border militarization than on climate finance for developing countries.

Australia's Operation Sovereign Borders is one example of a wealthy nation militarizing its borders just as climate-related displacement begins to intensify, and it is far from alone.
